Expectation1: Respect the mentor's time and availability.
Situation1: The mentor fit the session into the last hour before boarding a long flight.
Expectation2: Diagnose patient illnesses accurately based on symptoms and tests
Situation2: A patient with symptoms of the common cold has come in for a routine check-up.
Story: I glanced at the clock, feeling the weight of every passing minute. My mentor had squeezed in our session just before catching a long flight, and I knew how precious this hour was. I wanted to show respect, to be fully present, to ask thoughtful questions and absorb every bit of wisdom. But as I sat in my office, a patient with a runny nose and a cough waited outside, expecting a thorough check-up. I couldn’t ignore the possibility that something more serious might be hiding behind those common symptoms. My mind raced—if I rushed, I might miss a crucial detail; if I took my time, I’d disrespect my mentor’s tight schedule. The pressure built inside me, torn between my duty to my patient and my responsibility as a mentee. My phone buzzed with a reminder: “Mentor session in 10 minutes.” My heart pounded as I stared at the patient’s chart, caught in the impossible space between two worlds, each demanding my full attention.
